title: Understanding the Natural Logarithm Function
text: The natural logarithm function, ln(x), is only defined for positive values of $$x$$. This means that any expression inside the ln function must be greater than zero.

title: Setting the function argument greater than zero
text: Since $$ln(2-x)$$ is given, we need to find where $$2-x$$ is greater than zero. Solving the inequality $$2-x>0$$ will help us find the domain.

title: Solving the inequality
text: Solve the inequality $$2-x>0$$ to find the values of $$x$$ for which the function is defined.

title: Understanding Vertical Asymptotes
text: A vertical asymptote occurs where the function approaches $$\infty$$. For ln(x), this happens as the argument of the ln function approaches zero from the positive side.

title: Finding the Vertical Asymptote
text: Determine the value of $$x$$ where the expression inside the ln function becomes zero.
